intro: Dichocarpum pterigionocaudatum, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It features a rhizomatous root system and produces striking yellow-orange flowers in late summer. The plant has palmately lobed leaves that are typically hairy and have a rough texture. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it is relatively rare in cultivation.
